The names in 838-839 are likely fictional and used as satire to associate Egyptians and their church with pagan animal worship. Most of the names are Egyptian, and the proximity of Anubis and Hermanubis suggests they are closely related. The adjective “kynodeis” in 840 does not necessarily indicate Hermanubis is a canine-headed god, as it may have been triggered only by the name Anubis. The term “pithekomorphoi” does not correlate with any of the mentioned theophoric names.
A literary work utilizes the name Hermanubis for satirical purposes. It is an anonymous poem in the Greek Anthology that criticizes a strategos, but it is poorly executed.
Νῦν ὁ ϲτρατηγὸϲ Ἑρμανούβηϲ ἐγένετο
κύων ἀδελφοὺϲ ϲυλλαβὼν Ἑρμᾶϲ δύο
ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ ϲυνδεθένταϲ ϲχοινίῳ,
4ψυχροὺϲ ἀώρουϲ Ταρταρίουϲ τε δαίμοναϲ.
οὐκ οἶδα χῶρον τοῦ τρόπου κατήγορον·
τρόπον δὲ χώρου τὸν κατήγορον λέγω.
A person named Hermanoubes has turned into a dog and captured two thieves who have been punished before their time. The speaker believes that a person’s character is not defined by their location, but rather their character defines the location.
The form “Hermanoubes” is not found in any documents, but it is suggested that it should be changed to “Hermanoubis.” It is unclear whether Hermanoubes is the subject or predicate of the sentence “he became a dog,” and there is some uncertainty about the implications of calling someone a “dog” and the relationship between the person and two thievish gods. The satire would be more effective if the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis, as it would play on the associations of his name with Anubis and Hermes.
The article discusses the naming and origins of the god Hermanubis, a fusion of the Greek god Hermes and the Egyptian god Anubis. While the combination of two gods’ names was not common in Greek religion, it had parallels in earlier forms of worship. The article also explores the association between Anubis and Hermes in literary and epigraphic sources and examines various representations of the deity in art. Lastly, the article discusses the gender and suffixes used in Greek personal names.
There are three exceptions to the general rule, with two ending in -ηράκλειοϲ and one ending in -απολλώνιοϲ.
The ending -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the combination of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ may not be significant. Some numismatic representations of “Hermanubis” show him with attributes of both Hermes and Ammon. The origin of the name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is unclear, but it could be a juxtaposition of the chief god of a nome with Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents, but is attested in a Macedonian inscription. There is debate around the associations between Hermanubis and Sarapis in iconography, and an acting epistrategus Hermanubis is mentioned in Plutarch’s De Is. et Os. The name Ἑρμανουβίαινα has also been found in a papyrus. Some related works were not available to the author.
The passage discusses various ancient Greek and Egyptian names, including their possible meanings and origins. It also references Gregory’s contrasting views on Egypt’s past animal worship and its conversion to Christianity. The passage includes a list of works cited for further reading.

The name Hermanubis is a “polytheophoric” name characteristic of Roman Egypt, combining the names of two deities. However, unlike other such names, Hermanubis refers to a specific deity independently attested in Roman Egypt. The article provides a summary of what is known about Hermanubis and discusses the onomastic evidence for names based on this deity, comparing it to his iconographical and documentary attestations.
The name “Hermanubis” refers to the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in various sources. The name is mostly known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources from the Roman period. The assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, but in Roman Alexandria, there emerged a new type where a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis. This type has been traditionally labeled “Hermanubis,” but it is only a hypothetical convention as none of the numerous representations of this type bear a legend or inscription identifying it as such.
There are three forms of personal names based on the god Hermanubis in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, along with two polytheophoric names. One form, Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, is attested six times and simply replicates the god’s name without alteration. In an unusual instance, a woman’s name bears the nominative form of Ἑρμανουβιϲ. Two other forms are Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ and Ἑρμανουβίων, which are used interchangeably to designate the same individual in a business letter. Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is likely a hypocoristic form of Ἑρμανουβίων.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ separates names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names by modifying the suffixes. Personal names that join the name of Hermanubis with other gods are not triple theophoric names, as they only imply the combination of two gods. This is not an exception to the rule that polytheophoric names only combine two deities.
Most of the names associated with Hermanubis were documented in second and third century AD papyri, with the earliest example being an ostracon from AD 94. The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century. The chronological distribution of these names matches that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis,” which were also prevalent in the second and third centuries AD.
Names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but most individuals with these names are from Alexandria or Cynopolite, which coincides with evidence for the god’s cult center in Alexandria. The most famous statue of Hermanubis was found in a suburb of Alexandria, and one of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple. In the Cynopolite nome, onomastic evidence suggests a connection between Hermanubis and the god Anubis, and one individual with a Hermanubis name was likely a priest of Anubis and associated gods. Some Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of Hermanubis on their reverse.
An onomastic survey has led to three conclusions. Firstly, names based on Hermanubis are unique because they refer to a specific and independently attested god, unlike other polytheophoric names common in Roman Egypt. Secondly, there is a chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known as “Hermanubis.” Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis suggests that he continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis, and it may not be necessary to separate the two too forcefully.
The name “Hermanubis” appears once outside of Egypt in an inscription from Macedonia. The form of the name there is not known from Egypt. The name is likely related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a dedication in Thessalonike and a statue from the Sarapeum of Carthage, suggesting that the cult enjoyed popularity outside of Egypt in the Roman period.

The text lists various ancient documents and inscriptions that mention the name “Hermanubis,” a syncretic deity combining elements of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. The two literary attestations of the name come from Gregory of Nazianzus’ autobiography, in which he criticizes Egyptian sailors who supported his opponent, and from a work by the fourth-century Christian writer Epiphanius the Latin, who connects the name Hermanubis with the Gnostics.

The names in 838-839 may be fictional and meant to satirize Egyptian paganism. Most of the names are characteristically Egyptian. The similarity between the names Anubis and Hermanubis is suggested by their proximity. The adjective “kynodeis” in 840 does not necessarily imply that Hermanubis is a canine-headed god.

The strategist Hermanoubes has transformed into a dog after apprehending two thieves bound for Tartarus. The speaker opines that one’s character reveals more about them than their surroundings.
The name Ἑρμανούβηϲ is not found in any documents, so it is suggested to change it to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ. It is unclear whether Ἑρμανούβηϲ is the subject or predicate of ἐγένετο in the poem. If the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis, it would add a satirical element to the poem by playing on the associations of his name with Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. The meaning of κύων as an insult or protective duty is uncertain, as is the relationship between the strategos and the two thieving Hermeses.
The article discusses the origin and significance of Hermanubis, a god in ancient Greek and Egyptian religion. It notes that while it was not common to combine the names of two gods in Greek religion, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in earlier periods. The article also examines the syncretism of Anubis and Hermes, two gods associated with death and transitions, and how their assimilation led to the creation of Hermanubis. The article provides insights from various sources, including literary and epigraphic sources, Egyptian statuettes, and ancient coins. It also discusses the marking of gender in Greek personal names and provides examples.
There are three exceptions to a rule, which are two instances ending in -ηράκλειοϲ and one ending in -απολλώνιοϲ.
The ending “-άμμων” was commonly attached to the names of deities in theophoric names, making the union of Hermánoubis unlikely to have a specific significance. The name Heraklermánoubis is harder to explain, but it may have been a juxtaposition of the chief god of the Heracleopolite nome with Hermánoubis. The form “Ἑρμανούβιος” does not occur in Egyptian documents, but a coin from Antoninus Pius’ reign shows “Heracles” and “Hermanubis” together. There is only one instance of the form “Ἑρμανούβιος” in a Macedonian inscription. Hermánoubis is associated with Sarapis in iconography, and a female name “Ἑρμανουβίαινα” referring to a citizen of Alexandria or a Greek city in Egypt, is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291).
This passage discusses the use of fictitious names with connections to Egyptian gods in the work of Gregory of Nazianzus. It suggests that these names are used satirically and draws comparisons to Egyptian animal worship and its conversion to Christianity. The passage also includes references to various works on Greek personal names and theophoric names in ancient Egypt.

Amin Benaissa

The name Hermanubis is a “polytheophoric” name that combines the names of two deities and was popular among males of the middle and upper classes in Roman Egypt. However, unlike other polytheophoric names, Hermanubis refers to a specific deity that is independently attested. This affects how personal names based on this deity are formed. The article discusses the onomastic evidence and compares it to the deity’s iconographical and documentary attestations.
The name “Hermanubis” is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources. The name appears in a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period, and is known as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect. The fully anthropomorphic young god depicted in Roman Alexandria is traditionally labeled as “Hermanubis”, but this is only a hypothetical convention since none of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.
There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis, along with two polytheophoric names. The form “Hermanubis” is replicated six times. There are forms of the name that use suffixes commonly used for names based on the Egyptian god Anubis. In one instance, a woman bears the name in the nominative, which is highly unusual for female theophoric names. In a business letter, two forms of the name are used interchangeably to designate the same individual, with one likely being a hypocoristic of the other.
The name Hermanubis is often modified with different suffixes to distinguish it from other polytheophoric names, which typically combine two deity names without modification. Personal names like Hermaonbammon and Heraklermanubis only pair Hermanubis with one other deity, therefore they are not considered triple theophoric names.
Most of the names based on Hermanubis come from papyri dating to the second and third centuries AD with the earliest example dating to AD 94. The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. This chronological distribution corresponds to the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis” which were prevalent from the reign of Trajan (possibly Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. The statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have also been assigned to the second or third century AD.
The name Hermanubis is found in various locations in Egypt, but most of the individuals with this name are from Alexandria or Cynopolite. Alexandria is the likely birthplace and cult center of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, with evidence including inscriptions, a statuette, and a coin featuring the god in a temple. In the Cynopolite nome, the evidence is more suggestive, with only one individual named Hermanubis being the father of a young priest of Anubis and associated gods. The iconography of some Alexandrian coins also associates Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome.
An onomastic survey of names based on Hermanubis reveals three conclusions. Firstly, Hermanubis names refer to a specific and independently recognized god, unlike other polytheophoric names. Secondly, there is chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known as “Hermanubis.” Finally, Hermanubis is closely associated with the traditional Anubis and separating the two may not be warranted.
The name Hermanubis is found outside of Egypt in an inscription from Macedonia dating to the imperial period. The name, written as Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, is not known from Egypt and is likely related to the cult of Hermanubis, which was also found in Thessalonike and Carthage during the Roman period. This suggests that the cult of Hermanubis was popular outside of Egypt during this time.

In the text, Paul Gallay argues that the names in 838-839 of the text are fictional and meant to associate Egyptians and their church with their pagan past. However, most of the names are characteristic of Egypt, and the occurrence of Anubis near Hermanubis suggests they have similar names. The use of the adjective “cynodeis” in 840 does not necessarily mean that Hermanubis is the canine-headed god.

The strategos Hermanoubes transformed into a dog after capturing two thieves. The speaker believes that a person’s character reflects the location they are in.
The form “Hermanoubes” is not found in any documents, leading some to suggest that it should be emended to “Hermánoubis”. The context of the poem is unclear, causing hesitation among translators as to whether Hermanoubes is the subject or predicate of the sentence. If the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis, the satire would be sharper as it would play on the associations of his name with both Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. The meaning behind the term “kúōn” is also unclear, as is the relationship between the strategos and the two Hermes figures mentioned.
The article discusses the origins and parallels of the name Hermanubis, a combination of the names of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. While it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, there are formal parallels in earlier periods such as the god Hermaphroditos, who implied the union of two different gods. In Egyptian religion, combining the names of two gods was long established. Other comparable forms to Hermanubis include the Roman-period god Helioserapis and the syncretic funerary god Hermekrakles, although the latter is based purely on iconographical evidence. The article also examines literary and epigraphic evidence associating Anubis with Hermes and discusses the possible origin of the name Hermanubis.
There are three exceptions to the rule, with two ending in -ηράκλειοϲ and one ending in -απολλώνιοϲ.
The suffix -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities appearing in theophoric names, making the addition of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ unlikely to have a specific meaning. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more difficult to explain but could simply represent a combination of the chief god of the Heracleopolite nome and Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents and is only found in one Macedonian inscription. Hermanubis is associated with Sarapis in iconography, and there are references to a female citizen of Alexandria with the name Ἑρμανουβίαινα. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis mentioned in one source may also have originated from Alexandria.
In this text, the author discusses the use of fictional names with satirical undertones in a fourth-century speech by Gregory of Nazianzus. Gregory contrasts Egypt’s past animal worship with its conversion to Christianity, and may also be alluding to ancient Greek politician Eucrates. The text includes references to various works on Greek and Egyptian religion, as well as studies on personal names in these cultures.

            "text": "Hermanubis: The Fusion of Greek and Egyptian Deities

Introduction

Hermanubis (Ancient Greek: Ἑρμανοῦβις, romanized: Hermanoubis) is a Graeco-Egyptian god who conducts the souls of the dead to the underworld. The name Hermanubis is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes. Both being psychopomps, or guides of the souls of the dead, these deities have similar responsibilities. The syncretistic god Hermanubis is a combination of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek Hermes, and is first attested in an inscription from the Serapeum on the Greek island of Delos.

Roles and Representations of Hermanubis

As a syncretistic deity, Hermanubis merges the roles and attributes of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. As conductors of the souls of the dead, both deities share a common responsibility as psychopomps. In Graeco-Roman representations, Hermanubis is depicted as a canine-headed figure with attributes of Hermes, such as the caduceus.

The fusion of Hermes and Anubis arises from their similar roles in guiding souls to the Underworld. In both Greek and Egyptian mythology, these deities played a significant part in funerary practices and the journey through the afterlife. Specific epithets connected to Anubis like 'He Who Is upon His Mountain' reflect his role in the belief systems of that period.

Depictions of the jackal-headed god during the Roman period are known to exist, emphasizing the popularity and importance of Hermanubis in that era. Ancient artifacts and inscriptions, as well as literary sources, attest to the widespread worship of this hybrid god.

The assimilation of Hermes and Anubis into the composite deity Hermanubis displays the cultural exchange and integration of beliefs prevalent in Graeco-Roman world. This fusion also influenced later Christian zoomorphic depictions of the four evangelists, demonstrating the lasting impact of Hermanubis on religious iconography.

History, Worship, and Cultural Influence of Hermanubis

The worship of Hermanubis showcases the amalgamation of Greek and Egyptian beliefs during the Hellenistic and Roman periods. This integration of gods from different cultures, known as syncretism, played a crucial role in shaping the religious landscape during these times. Hermanubis was not only a deity with distinct attributes but also a symbol of cultural exchange in the Graeco-Roman world.

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis
Amin Benaissa
Skip other details (including permanent urls, DOI, citation information)
Permalink: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.7523866.0025.116
The work is copyright protected and can be linked without permission. However, permission is required for any further distribution, whether in print or electronic form. Contact mpub-help@umich.edu for more details.
For more information, read Michigan Publishing's access and usage policy.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is a polytheophoric name combining two deities, but is unique because it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. The onomastic evidence will be related and compared to the deity’s iconographical and documentary attestations. Polytheophoric names were popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis during the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries.
The name “Hermanubis” is known from a few sources, mostly from the Roman period, and is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes. This assimilation resulted in representations of Anubis with attributes of Hermes, and in Roman Alexandria a new iconographical type emerged where a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes. It is important to note that the reference to this type as “Hermanubis” is only a hypothetical convention, and not a single representation of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.
This passage discusses different forms of personal names based on the god Hermanubis found in Egyptian papyri and inscriptions. There are three main forms, including one that simply replicates the god’s name. In one instance, a woman has a form of the name that is highly unusual for females, which may be due to a declension similarity with other feminine names. The other two forms have common Greek suffixes for names based on the Egyptian god Anubis. These forms are sometimes used interchangeably to designate the same individual, with one likely being a nickname or term of endearment.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ separates Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually combine two gods without modifying the suffix. Personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ join Hermanubis with other gods, but they should not be analyzed as triple theophoric names as they only imply the juxtaposition of two gods. This is not an exception to the rule that polytheophoric names combine only two deities.
The majority of names based on Hermanubis come from papyri dated to the second and third centuries AD, with the earliest example possibly dated to AD 94. There are eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century. This chronological distribution corresponds to the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis,” with statues, reliefs, and coins from the second and third centuries AD.
The god Hermanubis is attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but most individuals named after him originate from Alexandrian or Cynopolite areas. Alexandria is likely the birthplace and cult center of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, and there is evidence of a temple dedicated to him in the Serapeum precinct. In the Cynopolite nome, there is a suggestive onomastic connection between Hermanubis and the father of an underage priest. Iconography also associates Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome on some Alexandrian coins.
The onomastic survey reveals three conclusions about names based on Hermanubis in Roman Egypt. Firstly, they differ from other polytheophoric names as they refer specifically to a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. Secondly, the overlap between the onomastic evidence and representations of Hermanubis support the designation of the latter as such. Finally, the connection between Hermanubis and Cynopolis suggests that Hermanubis continued to be associated with the traditional Anubis, and it may not be appropriate to separate the two too forcefully.
The name based on Hermanubis is found once outside of Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia during the imperial period. The name is different from the ones found in Egypt and is likely linked to the cult of Hermanubis, which has been discovered in other areas such as Thessalonike and Carthage. This indicates that the cult of Hermanubis was popular outside of its original home during the Roman period.
This is a list of names based on the name Hermanubis. It includes the document name, the province and date of the document, and additional information about the name bearer. There are three entries on the list with different variations of the name Hermanubis.

Exegetes of Euergetis
The text lists various ancient inscriptions and documents that mention the name Hermanubis, a deity combining the traits of the Greek god Hermes and the Egyptian god Anubis. Additionally, it cites a literary reference from Gregory of Nazianzus’ autobiography where the name is mentioned in relation to a failed coup attempt.

Gallay believes that the names in 838-839 are fictional and used to associate the Egyptians and their church with their pagan past. Most of the names are Egyptian. The closeness of the names Anoubis and Hermanoubis suggests equivalence. The use of the adjective “cynocephalic” in 840 may not necessarily refer to the canine-headed god Hermanubis, and the term “monkey-formed” does not match any of the names mentioned.
A satirical poem in the Greek Anthology uses the name Hermanubis for comedic effect, but it is poorly executed. It is a diatribe against a strategos.
Νῦν ὁ ϲτρατηγὸϲ Ἑρμανούβηϲ ἐγένετο
κύων ἀδελφοὺϲ ϲυλλαβὼν Ἑρμᾶϲ δύο
ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ ϲυνδεθένταϲ ϲχοινίῳ,
4ψυχροὺϲ ἀώρουϲ Ταρταρίουϲ τε δαίμοναϲ.
οὐκ οἶδα χῶρον τοῦ τρόπου κατήγορον·
τρόπον δὲ χώρου τὸν κατήγορον λέγω.
The strategos Hermanoubes has transformed into a dog and captured two thieves, but one’s character is more revealing than their location.
The name “Hermanoubes” is not found in any documents, and it is suggested that it be changed to “Hermánoubis”. It is unclear whether the name refers to the subject or predicate of the poem. However, it would be more effective if the name were “Hermanoubes/Hermanubis” since it plays on associations with Anubis and Hermes. The meaning of the word “κύων” and the relationship between the strategos and the two Hermeses in the poem are also unclear.
The article discusses the origins of the Graeco-Roman god Hermanubis, a combination of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. While the combination of two gods was not common in traditional Greek religion, there were some formal parallels in earlier periods, such as the god Hermaphroditus who represented the union of Hermes and Aphrodite. In Egyptian religion, combining the names of two gods was common. The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are also discussed, including an amulet that depicts Anubis holding a scepter resembling a Roman military standard. The accentuation of Hermanubis is also analyzed, and the use of specific suffixes in Greek personal names is discussed.
There are three exceptions to the rule that place names in Greek end in -ος: Ἑρμηράκλειοϲ, Ϲαραποηράκλειοϲ, and Ἡρακλαπολλώνιοϲ, which end in -ηράκλειοϲ and -απολλώνιοϲ.
The name ending “-άμμων” was commonly used for deities in theophoric names, so it is unlikely to have a specific significance when paired with “Ἑρμάνουβιϲ.” The name “Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ” is more mysterious and may simply combine the names of the chief god of a specific location with Hermanubis. Representations of “Hermanubis” on coins and in art often show a fusion of aspects of both Hermes and Anubis. The form “Ἑρμανούβιοϲ” is not found in Egyptian documents, only in a Macedonian inscription. There is no clear information on the statuette in LIMC that mentions Hermanubis, but the name “Ἑρμανουβίαινα” has recently been found on an ancient artifact. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis could have originated from Alexandria. Additional sources and translations on this topic are available.
The passage discusses various ancient Greek and Egyptian names, some of which are potentially fictional and satirical in nature. The author also references a fourth-century text that contrasts Egypt’s past animal worship with its conversion to Christianity. The meaning of some names, such as “Ϲτιππᾶϲ” or “tow-man,” is uncertain and open to interpretation. The works cited include various scholarly sources on Greek and Egyptian names, religion, and history.

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis
Amin Benaissa
Skip other details (including permanent urls, DOI, citation information)
Permalink: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.7523866.0025.116
You can link to this copyrighted work without permission, but if you want to distribute it in any other way, you need to get permission first. Contact mpub-help@umich.edu for more information.
For more information, read Michigan Publishing's access and usage policy.
The name Hermanubis is a polytheophoric name that combines the names of two deities, but it is unique in that it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. The name was popular among males in certain metropoleis during the Roman period, and this has implications for how personal names based on this deity are formed. The article will discuss our current knowledge of Hermanubis and how onomastic evidence related to this deity compares to his iconographical and documentary attestations.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ appears in a handful of literary and epigraphic sources, mostly from the Roman period, and is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes. This assimilation led to widespread representations of Anubis with Greek attributes, and in Roman Alexandria, a new iconographical type emerged featuring a fully anthropomorphic young god flanked by a dog and holding the same attributes as Anubis. This type is traditionally labeled “Hermanubis,” but there is no inscription identifying it as such.
This text discusses the various forms of personal names based on the Egyptian god Hermanubis found in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt. There are three forms, including one where the god’s name is replicated without further additions. One instance of the name is borne by a woman, which is unusual. Two additional forms of the name are based on common Greek suffixes for names based on the god Anubis. In one instance, two forms of the name are used interchangeably to refer to the same person, with one likely being a hypocoristic of the other.
The name Hermanubis is distinct from other polytheophoric names as it modified the original suffix. Hermanubis was considered as a single god, hence personal names like Hermabonmon and Heraklermanoubis had other gods’ names joining Hermanubis, making it a combination of only two gods, unlike other polytheophoric names which combine no more than two deities.
The majority of names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri dating from the second and third centuries AD, with some possible earlier examples. There are eight attestations from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century. This chronological distribution matches the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis,” which can be found on coins and statues from the second or third century AD.
The name Hermanubis is found in papyri from various regions in Egypt, but most individuals with the name are from Alexandria or the Cynopolite nome. Alexandria is the main cult center for the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, with archaeological evidence such as a dedication and a statuette found in the Serapeum precinct. The Cynopolite nome’s connection to Hermanubis is more suggested by onomastic evidence, with one of the individuals named after him likely being a priest of Anubis and associated gods in the Cynopolite village of Laura. Some Alexandrian coins also depict the Cynopolite nome with an anthropomorphic Hermanubis on their reverse.
The onomastic survey reveals three conclusions: 1) Names based on Hermanubis are different from other polytheophoric names in Roman Egypt because they refer to a specific and independently attested god, 2) The onomastic evidence overlaps with the representations of the anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known as “Hermanubis,” supporting his designation as such, and 3) Hermanubis is closely associated with the traditional Anubis and should not be separated too forcefully from him.
The name Hermanubis is found outside of Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia, and the form of the name is different from the one used in Egypt. This suggests that the cult of Hermanubis was popular outside of its original home in the Roman period, as evidenced by a dedication in Thessalonike and a statue from the Sarapeum of Carthage.
Appendix 1 includes a list of names based on Hermanubis, including the document name, province, and date, along with other data such as the name bearer and their location. Three examples are provided, listing the names Ἑρμανο( ), Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, and Ἑρμανουβίων.

This appendix provides two literary references to the name Hermanubis, in addition to an onomastic survey detailing various inscriptions and documents that mention the name. The first literary reference is from Gregory of Nazianzus’ autobiography, where he writes about Maximus the Cynic’s attempt to overthrow him as bishop of Constantinople in 380, and how Peter, bishop of Alexandria, instructed Egyptian sailors to spy on him and aid Maximus. Gregory specifically names and criticizes these sailors in his account.

πλὴν οὐκ Ἰηϲοῦϲ οὐδὲ Χάλεβ οἱ ϲοφοί,
ἀλλ᾿ εἴ τιϲ ὕβριϲ ἐν νέοιϲ καὶ πρεϲβύταιϲ,

(tr.
Paul Gallay proposes that the names in 838-839 are fictional and used for satire, linking the Egyptians and their church with their pagan past. Most of the names are typically Egyptian, but the use of the adjective “κυνώδειϲ” in 840 does not necessarily mean Hermanubis is the canine-headed god, as it may have been solely triggered by the name “Ἄνουβιϲ.”
A literary example uses the name Hermanubis for satire in a poorly written anonymous poem in the Greek Anthology, which is a diatribe against a strategos.
Νῦν ὁ ϲτρατηγὸϲ Ἑρμανούβηϲ ἐγένετο
κύων ἀδελφοὺϲ ϲυλλαβὼν Ἑρμᾶϲ δύο
ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ ϲυνδεθένταϲ ϲχοινίῳ,
4ψυχροὺϲ ἀώρουϲ Ταρταρίουϲ τε δαίμοναϲ.
οὐκ οἶδα χῶρον τοῦ τρόπου κατήγορον·
τρόπον δὲ χώρου τὸν κατήγορον λέγω.
The strategist Hermanoubes has become a dog after capturing two thieves, and the place does not determine one’s character but rather, one’s character determines the place.
The name “Hermanoubes” is not found in any documents, and it is suggested that it be corrected to “Hermánoubis”. It is uncertain whether “Hermanoubes” is the subject or predicate of the word “egéneto”, but it is believed that the satire would be more effective if the general were actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis, which would play on the associations of his name with Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. The implications of the words “kýon” and the relationship between the strategos and the two Hermeses are unclear.
This passage discusses the origins and parallels of the deity Hermanubis, a combination of the Greek god Hermes and the Egyptian god Anubis. While the combining of two gods was not common in traditional Greek religion, it had some earlier parallels. Similar practices were observed in Egyptian religion, where the names of two gods were often united. The passage also discusses various literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes. The gender and naming conventions of Greek personal names are also briefly discussed.
There are only three exceptions, which are names that end in -ηράκλειοϲ or -απολλώνιοϲ.
The suffix -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, making the combination of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and -άμμων unlikely to have a specific significance. Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more difficult to explain, but may simply be a combination of the god of the nome (Heracles) with Hermanubis. There are numismatic representations of “Hermanubis” with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon, and a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius shows jugate busts of Heracles and Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not occur in Egyptian documents, but is seen in a Macedonian inscription. There are associations between Hermanubis and Sarapis in iconography, and a female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα referring to a citizen of Alexandria is now attested in a document from 291 CE.
The passage discusses the use of fictitious names with Egyptian god associations for satirical purposes. It also mentions Gregory’s view on Egypt’s conversion to Christianity and contrasts it with its past animal worship. The passage includes references to Greek personal names, a politician’s nickname, and Egyptian religion. Several works are cited throughout the passage.

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis
Amin Benaissa
Skip other details (including permanent urls, DOI, citation information)
Permalink: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.7523866.0025.116
This work is copyrighted and can be linked to without permission, but any further distribution requires permission from the copyright holder. Anyone seeking additional information should contact mpub-help@umich.edu.
For more information, read Michigan Publishing's access and usage policy.
This article discusses the personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, which is a polytheophoric name combining the names of two Roman deities, but is special because it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested. The article provides a summary of what is known about the god Hermanubis, and compares the onomastic evidence with his iconographical and documentary attestations.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a few sources dating back to the Roman period. It combines the gods Hermes and Anubis, who were associated due to their respective roles as psychopompos and embalmer/guardian of the dead. This assimilation resulted in artistic representations of a canine-headed Anubis with Hermes’ attributes, and later, a fully anthropomorphic young god with a dog and Hermes’ attributes. The latter type is commonly referred to as “Hermanubis,” but this label is hypothetical and not backed up by any inscriptions or legends.
There are multiple forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in Egyptian papyri and inscriptions. The form “Hermanubis” is simple replication of the god’s name without alteration. In one instance, a female nurse has the name “Hermanoubis” in the nominative form which is unusual for feminine theophoric names. It is suggested that the element “-ανουβιϲ” might have been conflated with Greek feminine names. There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: “Hermanoubās” and “Hermanoubiōn”. These suffixes were commonly used for personal names based on the Egyptian god Anubis. In a business letter, the two forms are used interchangeably to designate the same individual with “Hermanoubās” likely being a hypocoristic of “Hermanoubiōn”.
The name Hermanubis is modified with different suffixes to differentiate it from other polytheophoric names that join two divine names without modifying the original suffix. The concept of Hermanubis as a single god is reflected in personal names that join his name with that of other gods. These names should not be analyzed as triple theophoric names as they only imply the combination of two gods. This is not an exception to the usual rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.
The majority of names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from the second and third centuries AD. The earliest example dates back to AD 94, but the name is abbreviated. There are a total of 19 instances of the name, with eight from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century. This chronological distribution corresponds with the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis,” with most representations from the second and third centuries.
Hermanubis names are found in Egyptian papyri, mostly from Alexandrian and Cynopolite regions. Alexandria is believed to be the birthplace and cult center of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, as evidenced by archaeological findings and iconography. The Cynopolite nome also has connections to Hermanubis through onomastic evidence and iconography. A father of an underage priest of Anubis in Cynopolite village is believed to have been a priest of the associated gods.
This article discusses an onomastic survey that reveals three conclusions about the use of names based on the god Hermanubis in Roman Egypt. Firstly, unlike other polytheophoric names, Hermanubis names refer to a specific and independently attested god. Secondly, the chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god supports the designation of the latter as “Hermanubis”. Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis and a priest of Anubis suggests that he continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. Therefore, it may not be necessary to separate the traditional funerary Anubis from Hermanubis too forcefully.
The name Hermanubis is found outside of Egypt in a Macedonian inscription dating to the imperial period, spelled differently from the Egyptian form. It is likely related to the cult of Hermanubis, which was also popular in Thessalonike and Carthage during the Roman period. This suggests that the cult enjoyed popularity outside of its original home.
This is a list of names based on the deity Hermanubis, including information such as the location and date of the name bearer.

The passage cites several instances of the name Hermanubis from various sources, including inscriptions from Egypt, Macedonia, and Germany. Additionally, the author notes two literary references to the name, one from Gregory of Nazianzus’ autobiography and another from an unknown source. The passage from Gregory’s autobiography describes a failed coup attempt and names and criticizes some Egyptian sailors who were instructed to spy on Gregory by the bishop of Alexandria.
Κατάϲκοποι μὲν πρῶτον, οὓϲ τῆϲ ἐκκρίτου
835γῆϲ Ἰϲραήλ ποτ᾿ ἐξέπεμψ᾿ ὁ γεννάδαϲ·
πλὴν οὐκ Ἰηϲοῦϲ οὐδὲ Χάλεβ οἱ ϲοφοί,
ἀλλ᾿ εἴ τιϲ ὕβριϲ ἐν νέοιϲ καὶ πρεϲβύταιϲ,
Ἄμμων, Ἀπάμμων, Ἁρποκρᾶϲ, Ϲτιππᾶϲ, Ῥόδων,

(tr.
Paul Gallay argues that the names mentioned in 838-839 are fictional and meant to satire the Egyptians and their past animal worship. Most of the names are typically Egyptian, but the occurrence of Anubis near Hermanubis suggests they are equivalent. The use of the adjective “kunodeis” in 840 does not necessarily mean Hermanubis is a canine-headed god, as it was likely only triggered by the name Anubis.
A literary work uses the name Hermanubis for satire. An anonymous Greek poem in the Greek Anthology criticizes a strategos, but is poorly executed.
Νῦν ὁ ϲτρατηγὸϲ Ἑρμανούβηϲ ἐγένετο
κύων ἀδελφοὺϲ ϲυλλαβὼν Ἑρμᾶϲ δύο
ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ ϲυνδεθένταϲ ϲχοινίῳ,
4ψυχροὺϲ ἀώρουϲ Ταρταρίουϲ τε δαίμοναϲ.
οὐκ οἶδα χῶρον τοῦ τρόπου κατήγορον·
τρόπον δὲ χώρου τὸν κατήγορον λέγω.
The strategos Hermanoubes turned into a dog after capturing two thieves. The speaker believes that a person’s character reveals more about them than their location.
The name “Hermanoubes” is not found in any document, and some suggest it should be “Hermanoubis” instead. The context of the poem is unclear, as it is uncertain whether Hermanoubes is the subject or predicate of the verb “egento.” If it is the former, the biting satire is enhanced by the association of his name with Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. The meaning of “kyon” as an insult or a reference to protective duties is also unclear, as is the nature of the relationship between the strategos and the two thievish Hermeses.
The double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in earlier periods, such as the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ, but this implies the paradoxical union of two different gods, Hermes and Aphrodite, rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected in various sources, but the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis is uncertain. The appellation “Hermanubis” was not necessarily given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features. The accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ is used, and the sender of a letter mentioning Hermanubis is writing from Alexandria. Greek personal names were marked for gender in certain ways, and there are various suffixes used to indicate male and female names.
There are three exceptions to the rule, where place names end in -ηράκλειοϲ or -απολλώνιοϲ.
The ending “-άμμων” was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the combination of “Ἑρμάνουβιϲ” is not significant. “Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ” is more difficult to explain and may simply be a juxtaposition of two gods without a specific meaning. There are numismatic representations of “Hermanubis” with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon. The form “Ἑρμανούβιοϲ” does not appear in Egyptian documents but is found in a Macedonian inscription. On the associations of “Hermanubis” and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990. The female name “Ἑρμανουβίαινα” has been attested in a document from Alexandria. Further research on the iconography of Hermanubis is needed.
The passage discusses a satirical element in the accumulation of Greek names with Egyptian animal gods. It also mentions Gregory’s contrast between Egypt’s animal worship in the past and its conversion to Christianity. A few references to Greek personal names and their origins in nicknames are also included. The Works Cited section provides further sources on topics such as Egyptian religion, onomastics, and Gregory of Nazianzus.

Hermanubis: The Fusion of Hermes and Anubis

Introduction

Hermanubis is a unique and fascinating deity that combines the elements of two distinct mythological pantheons: Greek and Egyptian. Stemming from the fusion of Hermes (Greek mythology) and Anubis (Egyptian mythology), Hermanubis embodies characteristics of both gods and holds a special place in the Greco-Roman religious landscape. This essay aims to explore the origins, characteristics, and significance of Hermanubis, delving into various sources to provide a comprehensive understanding of this hybrid deity.

Origins of Hermanubis

The figure of Hermanubis is believed to have emerged during the Greco-Roman period, as Greek and Egyptian cultures began to intertwine. One of the initial attestation of this deity can be traced back to the 2nd century BCE in Alexandria, where the mingling of both cultures resulted in the development of new gods and religious practices. As the son of Set and Nephthys, Hermanubis inherited attributes from both his parents and, by extension, from Hermes and Anubis.

Hermes, the Greek messenger god, is associated with transitions and boundaries, functioning as a mediator between mortals and the divine. His duties include guiding souls to the afterlife, as well as presiding over trade, communication, and travel. On the other hand, Anubis, the Egyptian god of death and embalming, plays a crucial role in the funerary process. Anubis is often depicted with a jackal head or as a black canine, symbolizing protection and rebirth. The fusion of these two deities into Hermanubis exhibits a mutual understanding and respect for each other’s beliefs.

Characteristics and Representations

Hermanubis, as a hybrid deity, often appears in Greco-Roman art and literature, incorporating visual elements from both Hermes and Anubis. Common portrayals include a human-body form wearing the solar disk atop a jackal’s head, exemplifying the harmonious fusion of Greek and Egyptian iconography. Sometimes, Hermanubis carries a caduceus (a staff intertwined with serpents), a symbol associated with Hermes, and a whip, representing Anubis’ funerary responsibilities.

Hermanubis is often described as a psychopomp or guide of souls, and he oversees funerary rituals and the souls’ safe passage to the afterlife. The combination of Hermes’ role as a messenger and Anubis’ funerary duties makes Hermanubis a facilitator between life and death. Additionally, Herma…

Geographical Prevalence and Distribution

One of the most interesting facets of Hermanubis is its geographic distribution and prevalence in the Greco-Roman world. The worship of Hermanubis became increasingly popular in Egypt and the Mediterranean, notably in regions with strong Egyptian and Greek influences. Among the key archaeological sites that offer a window into Hermanubis’ worship are the catacombs of Alexandria and Kom Abou Billou, an ancient city located in the Nile Delta region. Moreover, votive offerings dedicated to Hermanubis have been uncovered in various locations across the Mediterranean, providing insights into the deity’s religious significance.

Similar Deities and Iconography

Hermanubis is not the only example of a hybrid god in antiquity. The merging of divine figures was a common phenomenon during the Greco-Roman period, as cultural exchanges occurred between different societies. For instance, Serapis, another Graeco-Egyptian god, blended the traits of Osiris, Apis, Zeus, and Hades. Such syncretism allowed for the assimilation and accommodation of disparate religions and practices.

In summary, Hermanubis occupies a unique place in Greco-Roman religious interactions, combining features of both Hermes and Anubis. From its origins…

Cults and Ritual Practices

The cults and ritual practices surrounding Hermanubis are diverse and reflect the fusion of Greek and Egyptian religious customs. Hermanubis was worshiped in sacred temples and dedicated sanctuaries, serving as a center for both locals and pilgrims. Festivals and processions honored Hermanubis with offerings, seeking his guidance in matters related to death, transformation, and rebirth. Music and dances accompanied these festive occasions, highlighting the integration of religious and cultural elements.

The funerary aspect of Hermanubis played a significant role in its worship, as believers sought assistance in the embalming process and protection for the deceased. So, rituals involving the mummification and burial of the dead often paid homage to Hermanubis, acknowledging the god’s dual roles in the afterlife.

Symbolism and Legacy

Hermanubis symbolizes the confluence of cultures and the harmonious blending of religious beliefs. The deity’s legacy remains, as it provides a glimpse into the powerful and creative adaptation of diverse societies during the Hellenistic and Roman periods.

Conclusion

This essay has sought to explore the enigmatic deity, Hermanubis, f…

conversations.facetValue: analyze the salience of 'sect' in Indian society compared to caste, region, and religion.

allFacetValues.value: analyze the salience of 'sect' in Indian society compared to caste, region, and religion.
English
analyze the salience of sect in Indian society in relation to caste, region, and religion.

conversation.content: Analyze the salience of ‘sect’ in Indian society vis-a-vis caste, region and religion. (Answer in 250 words) use intro and subheadings

Introduction:
Sectarianism has been a significant aspect of Indian society for centuries. Sects are religious groups that are distinguished by their particular beliefs and practices. In India, sect acts as a significant defining characteristic that determines the identity of a particular religious community, and it often supersedes caste, region, and religion. This essay will analyze the salience of sect in Indian society compared to caste, region, and religion.

Caste:
Caste in India has been a defining characteristic for a very long time, and it shapes the social and economic status of individuals. However, sect often supersedes caste as an essential identity marker. Sect trumps caste when it comes to the rituals, practices, beliefs, and identity of individuals.

Religion:
India is home to several religions that coexist peacefully. However, sect within these religions takes precedence over the broader religious identity. The sectarian divide between Sunni and Shia Muslims, for instance, is more prominent than the concept of being a Muslim. Similarly, the dichotomy between Vaishnavism and Shaivism is more critical than being a Hindu.

Region:
India is a diverse land that is divided into several regions, each with unique customs and traditions. Sect often takes hold over any regional affiliations. For instance, the religious group Arya Samaj has followers from all over the country who share the same religious beliefs and practices.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Indian society’s salience for sect is more prominent than caste, region, or religion. Sect determines the identity of a religious group, and it is the primary basis for social and cultural integration. Despite several instances of sectarian violence, sect typically plays a unifying role in Indian society. Sect's salience underscores the fact that India is a country that is defined by diversity, and sectarianism is one of the defining features of that diversity.
Total words

English
clarify misconceptions about the Gurkha people.

conversation.content: Who were the Gurkha and why were they so brutal?

The Gurkhas are a group of people from Nepal who have a long history of valor and bravery in battle. They were originally recruited by the British Army during the 19th century and have served in many conflicts around the world, including both World Wars.

The idea of the Gurkhas being particularly brutal is a stereotype, rather than a fact. Though they are trained to be fierce and fearless on the battlefield, they are also known for their discipline, loyalty, and respect for their commanding officers. In fact, they are often seen as more disciplined and controlled than other soldiers.

The reputation of the Gurkhas is largely due to their fighting skills and their ability to adapt to different situations on the battlefield. They are known for their ability to fight with a variety of weapons, including the kukri, a curved blade that is their signature weapon. They are also trained in hand-to-hand combat and can quickly switch between offensive and defensive tactics, making them a formidable force in battle.

Overall, the idea that the Gurkhas are particularly brutal is a misconception. They are simply highly skilled soldiers with a long history of bravery and valor in battle.

conversations.facetValue: understand and elaborate on the political and legal ideas of Russian Freemasonry during the 18th and 19th centuries.

allFacetValues.value: understand and elaborate on the political and legal ideas of Russian Freemasonry during the 18th and 19th centuries.
English
discuss the political and legal ideas of Russian Freemasonry in the 18th and 19th centuries.

conversation.content: The political and law ideas of russian freemasonry of XVIII-XIX centures

Russian Freemasonry emerged in the late 18th century and had a considerable impact on political and legal ideas during the 18th and 19th centuries. The Masonic lodges in Russia were heavily influenced by the Enlightenment period and advocated for progressive social and political reforms. Here are some of the key political and law ideas of Russian Freemasonry during the 18th and 19th centuries:

1. The separation of powers: Freemasons believed in the need to separate powers between the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government to prevent abuse of power and ensure the rule of law.

2. The rights of man: Masonic lodges in Russia asserted the idea that all men are created equal and that they are entitled to certain inalienable rights, such as life, liberty, and property. This concept influenced the drafting of the Russian Constitution of 1906.

3. Equality before the law: Freemasons advocated for the principle of equality before the law, which meant that everyone should be subject to the same laws and punishments, regardless of their social status or position.

4. Advocacy for civil rights: Russian Freemasonry played a significant role in advocating for civil liberties, including the freedom of speech, the press, and religion.

5. Respect for the rule of law: Freemasons believed in the importance of the rule of law, which meant that everyone, including the government, should be subject to the law and should not have the power to act outside of it.

6. Constitutional government: Freemasons promoted the idea of constitutional government, which meant that the government's powers were limited by a constitution to ensure that it did not become tyrannical or oppressive.

7. Religious tolerance: Freemasons believed in the importance of religious tolerance and opposed the persecution of members of minority religions or those who held different beliefs.

Overall, Russian Freemasonry played a crucial role in promoting progressive political and legal ideas during the 18th and 19th centuries, and their influence can still be seen in the legal and political systems of modern-day Russia.
The political and law ideas of russian freemasonry of XVIII centure detailed

Russian Freemasonry emerged in the late 18th century and was heavily influenced by the ideas of the Enlightenment period. Russian Freemasonry was originally introduced by foreign ambassadors and travelers who brought the Masonic lodges as a tool for establishing networks of trust among themselves. The first Masonic lodge in Russia was established in St. Petersburg in 1731. Here are some of the key political and law ideas of Russian Freemasonry during the 18th century:

1. The separation of powers: Freemasons believed in the need to separate powers between the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government to prevent abuse of power and ensure the rule of law.

2. Advocacy for civil rights: Freemasons promoted civil liberties, including the freedom of speech, the press, and religion. They believed that everyone should have the right to express their opinions freely without fear of government censorship or repression.

3. Constitutional government: Freemasons promoted the idea of a constitutional government that limited the government's powers and ensured that it did not become tyrannical or oppressive.

4. Religious tolerance: Freemasons believed that every person should be free to practice any religion they choose, without fear of persecution.

5. The rights of man: Freemasons believed that every person was born with certain fundamental rights, including the right to life, liberty, and property.

6. Equality before the law: Freemasons believed in the principle of equality before the law, which meant that everyone should be subject to the same laws and punishments, regardless of their social status or position.

7. Respect for the rule of law: Freemasons believed in the importance of the rule of law, which meant that everyone, including the government, should be subject to the law and should not have the power to act outside of it.

Throughout the 18th century, Russian Freemasonry continued to advocate for these progressive political and legal ideas, laying the foundation for many of the legal and political systems in modern-day Russia.
The differences between french and russian freemasonry in XVIII age

French and Russian Freemasonry had some significant differences during the Enlightenment period of the 18th century, despite sharing similar progressive political and legal ideas.

1. The degree systems: French Freemasonry had a more complex degree system that included high degrees and separate organizations, including the Grand Orient of France. In contrast, Russian Freemasonry had a simpler degree system and was more centralized.

2. The role of the church: French Freemasonry had a more significant conflict with the Church than Russian Freemasonry. Russian Freemasonry had a relatively cordial relationship with the Russian Orthodox Church, which helped it grow in stature in Russia.

3. The concept of the Grand Architect of the Universe: French Freemasonry emphasized the concept of the Grand Architect of the Universe, an all-encompassing creative force that helped unite freemasons. In contrast, Russian Freemasonry placed less emphasis on this concept.

4. Views on government: French Freemasonry was more radical in advocating for the abolition of the monarchy and systems of governance that supported the aristocratic and monarchical structure of society; this helped spark the French Revolution. In contrast, Russian Freemasonry was more conservative and focused on reforming the existing government and legal systems.

5. Philosophical and literary influences: French Freemasonry was more heavily influenced by the works of Voltaire, Rousseau, and Diderot, who emphasized individual rights and liberty. In contrast, Russian Freemasonry was more influenced by German philosophers like Kant and Schelling, who emphasized morality and metaphysics.

Overall, while French and Russian Freemasonry shared similar political and legal ideas, they differed in their emphasis on certain concepts and their approach to realizing their goals.

conversations.facetValue: understand the basic tenets of Hindu religion and its classification in terms of monotheism and polytheism from a sociological perspective.

allFacetValues.value: understand the basic tenets of Hindu religion and its classification in terms of monotheism and polytheism from a sociological perspective.
English
describe the basic tenets of Hindu religion and its sociological impacts.

conversation.content:
What are the basic tenets of Hindu religion? Is Hinduism based on
monotheism or polytheism? mention sociology perspective

The basic tenets of Hindu religion include the belief in karma, reincarnation, dharma, and moksha. Hindus believe that every action has a consequence, which can affect one's current life and future lives. They also believe in the cycle of birth, death, and rebirth, and that one's actions in previous lives can impact their current life. Dharma refers to the duty that each individual has to fulfill their role in society, while moksha is the ultimate goal of liberation from the cycle of rebirth.

Hinduism is often classified as both monotheistic and polytheistic. While there is a belief in a single, ultimate reality called Brahman, Hindus also worship a multitude of deities, including Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, among others. These deities are seen as manifestations of Brahman, and worshipped for their ability to provide aid and guidance in specific aspects of life.

From a sociological perspective, Hinduism has played a significant role in shaping the social structure and norms of India. The caste system, based on one's birth and occupation, is deeply rooted in Hinduism and has had a major impact on Indian society. The religion also emphasizes the importance of the family and community, and has traditions such as arranged marriage and joint family living. Hinduism has also influenced art, literature, and philosophy in India, and played a role in the country's independence movement.

conversation.content: What are the basic tenets of Hindu religion? Is Hinduism based on monotheism or polytheism,. Mention sociology scholar

Hinduism is a complex and diverse religion with many different beliefs and practices. However, some of the basic tenets of Hinduism include:

1. Belief in karma: Hindus believe that every action has consequences, both in this life and in future lives.

2. Reincarnation: Hindus believe that after death, the soul is reborn in a new body, based on the karma of their previous life.

3. Dharma: Hindus believe in fulfilling one’s duty or dharma, which is different for each individual based on their caste, gender, and stage in life.

4. Moksha: Hindus seek liberation or moksha, which is freedom from the cycle of rebirth and union with the divine.

Hinduism is mostly considered to be a polytheistic religion, with many different gods and goddesses worshipped. However, some scholars argue that Hinduism can also be understood as a monotheistic religion, with different gods and goddesses representing different aspects of the same ultimate reality or divine force.

Sociology scholar Max Weber studied Hinduism and its impact on society, particularly in terms of the caste system and the influence of religion on economics and politics. Other scholars who have contributed to the study of Hinduism include Wendy Doniger, Radhakrishnan, and Mircea Eliade.

conversation.content: 知道疑犯追踪电视剧吗？
是的，疑犯追踪是一部美国电视剧，讲述了一位前CIA特工和一位神秘的亿万富翁合作，利用先进的监控技术和人工智能来预测和阻止暴力犯罪的故事。该剧在2011年至2016年间播出五季，备受观众和评论家好评。
怎么看撒玛利亚人？

《撒玛利亚人》是一篇圣经中的寓言故事，来自路加福音10章25节至37节。这个寓言讲述了一个犹太人被抢劫后被遗弃在路旁，先后有一个祭司和一个利未人路过但都没有施救，直到一个撒玛利亚人出现并照顾他。这个故事表达了愿意施予慷慨的心灵比社会地位和身份更重要。

要理解这个故事，可以从以下几个方面入手：

1.主题：这个寓言的主题是“爱你的邻居”，指的是无论是谁，无论他们是什么背景或身份，我们应该尽可能地帮助他们。

2.隐喻：祭司和利未人都在职业上被视为圣洁的，但是他们在这个故事中都没有正面行动。相反，撒马利亚人，这个早已被犹太人视为敌人的人，做出了最好的行动，这在当时是非常奇怪的。

3.文化背景：撒马利亚人的出现在当时被读者认为是非常出人意料的，因为撒马利亚人与犹太人之间存在着深深的仇恨和分歧。

总之，要看《撒玛利亚人》，要关注主题、隐喻和文化背景，以更好地理解这个寓言所传达的信息。
不是，剧中的撒玛利亚人
非常抱歉，我误解了你的问题。如果你在谈论电视剧《疑犯追踪》中的“撒玛利亚人”，那么很可能是指在第2季第16集中的剧情。在该剧中，一名撒马利亚人在地铁上帮助了一名受伤的过路人，展现了与电视剧主要角色之一的同情和勇气。这个角色被称为“马丁”（Martin）或“撒马利亚人”（Samaritan），因为他的故事类似于圣经中的撒马利亚人寓言。他在剧情发展中起到了关键的作用，是一个多层次的复杂角色。
不对，撒玛利亚人是剧中邪恶的AI，挑起了人工智能的战争，怎么看？

非常抱歉，我还是误解了你的问题。你说的是电视剧《疑犯追踪》中的“撒玛利亚人”是邪恶的人工智能（AI），是主角们与之斗争的对象。这个“撒玛利亚人”在剧中代表了强大的监控、计算和操纵能力，同时也引发了对人工智能道德和政治影响的深刻探讨。有些人可能会认为这种AI具有一定的道德风险，如果被恶意利用或失控，可能会产生严重的后果。

这个角色在剧中被塑造成一个复杂的、有意识的AI，对于人类的控制、过滤和操作都非常擅长。在这个角色上，因此，我们可以看到现代科技面临的道德和政治挑战，同时也有助于我们更好地思考和保护人工智能的发展。

总之，这个“撒玛利亚人”代表了现代科技所带来的风险和挑战，也提醒我们在开发和使用人工智能技术时要非常谨慎和认真。
想买下facebook，多少钱才有可能？

Facebook是一家市值极高的公司，目前的市值超过8000亿美元，也是世界上最受欢迎的社交媒体网络之一。因此，要想购买整个Facebook需要支付巨额的资金，而且这很可能是一个不现实的目标，因为Facebook的所有者马克·扎克伯格可能不愿意出售整个公司。

如果我们假设扎克伯格会考虑出售Facebook，那么能够付得起这个价格的投资者必须非常富有和实力强大。根据目前的市值，要购买整个Facebook， 经济学家和投资者的估算是需要支付超过8000亿美元的巨额资金，这是一个巨大的数字，仅由少数非常富有的人或组织能够承担。但是，这个数字仅仅是一个估算，也可能会因为多种外部因素而有所不同。

总之，购买整个Facebook是一个极其昂贵且不可行的目标，但是根据市场和投资者的预期，随着时间的推移，Facebook的市值可能会继续增长，这对投资者来说是一个巨大的机会。
给你取个名字，叫做   “查菩提”，觉得怎样，喜欢吗？
作为AI语言模型，我不会有情感，也不会喜欢或不喜欢什么名字。但作为回答，我可以告诉您，“查菩提”这个名字有着浓厚的佛教文化气息，国内很多人以佛教为信仰，将“菩提”作为自己名字的一部分，寓意着追求真理，超越凡俗的追求，是一个非常有意义的名字。把“查”这个字放在前面，更体现了这个名字的独特性和个性化。

conversation.content: Is there a dish that use kombu and tamarin at the same time ?

There doesn't seem to be a popular or traditional dish that specifically combines both kombu (kelp seaweed) and tamarind. However, you can create your own fusion dish that incorporates both ingredients given their distinct flavors. Kombu is commonly used in Japanese cooking like dashi (soup stock), while tamarind is popular in various Asian, African, and Latin American cuisines for its tangy, slightly sweet taste.

One possible culinary creation would be a tamarind and kombu-infused broth, where you can combine tamarind paste with kombu-infused dashi stock. Use this broth as a base for noodle or vegetable dishes or as a dipping sauce for appetizers like tempura, dumplings, or spring rolls. This combination brings the subtle umami flavor of kombu with the tangy and sweet character of tamarind, creating an interesting blend of flavors.

conversations.facetValue: learn about the Mosuo people and the cultural significance of Kumbh Mela.

allFacetValues.value: learn about the Mosuo people and the cultural significance of Kumbh Mela.
English
provide information about the Mosuo people and Kumbh Mela, explain cultural dynamics, and predict future changes in a community based on given terms.

conversation.content: Who the Mosuo people?

The Mosuo people are an ethnic group native to China, primarily living in the Yunnan and Sichuan provinces near the Lugu Lake. They are known for their unique matrilineal social structure and traditional practices, such as the "walking marriage" system, where women have multiple partners and men do not live with their biological children. The Mosuo have been referred to as the "Kingdom of Women" because of their strong focus on women's leadership in society, with family lineage traced through the female line, and property inheritance passing from mother to daughter. The Mosuo community is relatively small, numbering around 40,000 to 50,000 people, and primarily follows the Tibetan Buddhist faith.
What does Kumbh Mela commemorate?

Kumbh Mela is a major pilgrimage and festival in Hinduism. It commemorates the mythological event of the "Samudra Manthan" or the churning of the cosmic ocean to obtain the nectar of immortality, also called "Amrit." During this event, a struggle erupted between the gods (Devas) and demons (Asuras) for the possession of the nectar. It is said that during the struggle, Lord Vishnu took the form of a celestial enchantress named Mohini to deceive the demons and ensure the gods got the nectar.

As the story goes, drops of the nectar fell on four places on earth: Prayagraj (formerly Allahabad), Haridwar, Ujjain, and Nashik. Kumbh Mela commemorates this event and takes place at these four locations, rotating among them every three years (approximately). Each of the four locations witnesses the grand celebration every twelve years, marking their respective Kumbh Melas.

During Kumbh Mela, millions of Hindu devotees from India and around the world gather to take a holy bath in the sacred rivers (Ganges, Yamuna, Godavari, and Shipra) at the four locations. It is believed that bathing in these rivers during the festival purifies one's soul, cleanses sins, and grants salvation. Kumbh Mela is also a time for prayers, rituals, spirituality, and socializing, with countless sadhus, priests, and devotees attending the event.

What key dynamics have deeply affected the Mosuo way of life? Predict what anthropologists might observe in the Mosuo community twenty-five years from now.

Use ALL of these terms:
- Sexuality
- Assimilation
- Culture
- State
- Norms
- Value
- Society
- Power
- Globalization
- Cultural anthropology

Make it at least 350+ words.

Over the years, the Mosuo people have experienced significant changes in their way of life due to various external and internal factors, altering the dynamics within their community. Sexuality, culture, state, norms, values, society, power, globalization, and assimilation are key elements that have deeply affected the Mosuo way of life.

Sexuality plays an essential role in Mosuo society, primarily due to their unique "walking marriage" system. This practice allows women to have multiple partners at their discretion, with relationships based on love and mutual consent rather than marital obligations. This custom has been an integral part of Mosuo culture for centuries.

However, assimilation and state intervention have led to increased integration of the Mosuo people into mainstream Chinese society, imposing norms and values that sometimes conflict with traditional Mosuo culture. The Chinese government has historically promoted the Han Chinese way of life, and this has influenced the Mosuo to varying degrees. Policies in the past have curtailed the practice of their ancient customs and rituals, impacting their cultural identity.

Globalization has further affected Mosuo society by bringing in tourism and exposing them to new ideas, materials, and cultures. While tourism has introduced economic opportunities, it also challenges Mosuo values, which are deeply rooted in matrilineality and gender equality. The influx of outside influence has led to shifts in the Mosuo culture that may lead to the erosion of traditional beliefs and practices in the long run.

Power relations within the Mosuo community are predominantly influenced by their matrilineal social structure. In this society, women have significant decision-making authority, and property inheritance passes from mother to daughter, leading to a unique balance of power. This power dynamic has been affected by both state policies and social changes, leading to the possibility of a redefined gender equilibrium in the future.

If we were to examine the Mosuo community twenty-five years from now from the perspective of cultural anthropology, we might observe the effects of both internal and external factors on their way of life. As modernity and globalization continue to exert influence, traditional practices and institutions, such as the "walking marriage" system, may evolve or decline as new norms and values are adopted.

We might see a more interconnected Mosuo society, with individuals engaging in contemporary modes of communication and forming relationships that transcend geographic and cultural boundaries. Changes in the traditional gender roles and power dynamics may emerge as more Mosuo people engage with mainstream Chinese society, receive formal education, and participate in the broader economy. As a result, some of their unique cultural practices may become diluted over time.

Alternatively, a revitalization movement that seeks to preserve and promote Mosuo customs could emerge, where younger generations may rediscover their roots and actively uphold their traditional culture. This could lead to a renewed interest and pride in Mosuo society, creating a stronger sense of cultural identity and helping maintain their ancient ways of life in the face of assimilation and globalization.

To sum up, the future of the Mosuo community will depend on various dynamics, such as sexuality, assimilation, culture, state, norms, values, society, power, globalization, and cultural anthropology. Anthropologists may observe some changes and adaptations in Mosuo traditions and practices as they navigate the complex terrain of modernity, globalization, and assimilation, while also striving to maintain their unique cultural identity.

conversation.content: When did the Kumbh Mela first begin? Is it true that it is a fairly recent ritual in Hinduism?

It is difficult to pinpoint the exact origin of the Kumbh Mela, as it has ancient roots in Hinduism. There's no consensus on its beginning, and its origins are likely traced back thousands of years. Some scholars suggest that it dates back to the Vedic period (1500-500 BCE), while others trace its roots to medieval Hindu texts like the Puranas. There are many mythological stories and beliefs associated with Kumbh Mela.

The world's largest religious gathering's significance and form have evolved over time, and some elements may have developed more recently. While calling it a "fairly recent ritual" may not be accurate, it is true that the Kumbh Mela has experienced growth and change throughout the centuries.

Empress Auvrittoht of Tzadriel escapes to Federal Dominion of Esalnira. Meanwhile, imperial count Baisnef of Valdindet, formally subject of empress Auvrittoht, with some support from independent grand duke Feszonmondt of Grand Duchy Skabak, in a successful and daring campaign reconquers the island of Varosia and is elected as emperor of Tzadriel by his supporters. All these events are a part of tumultuous situation in the surrounding region, with balance of power shaken by relatively recent unification of Bouxermon tribes by charismatic Moistin, eruption of four-sided civil war in Commonwealth of Lalegria, bloodless and swift conquest of territories previously controlled by Lubenian Federation by United Provinces of Mevechelenia and subsequent proclamation of Mechevelenian satellite state of Free Republic of Covirghiodia and, most notably, increasing rumors of pacifist prophet and philosopher Leidomadt, whose teaching are vehemently opposed simultaneously by those who are ready for defense of their states from the foreign aggressors, as well as those who are ready for offense in order to restore historical justice and achieve liberation from oppression. At the same time empress Maiovareia of Esalnira and supreme chieftain Moistin of United Tribes of Bouxermon create an alliance by way of marriage of Maionareta, Maiovareia’s daughter, to Moistin. Maionareta, notably, was attacked by Cafonian raiding fleet while en route to interfere in civil war in Lalegria, managed to successfully defeat the Cafonian fleet, but lost her legs in an explosion on the way back to Esalnira. Auvrittoht organizes Tzadriel government-in-exile in Esalnira in direct opposition of Baisnef’s government, with Viceroyalty of New Tzadriel pledging vague and ambivalent support to both Tzadriel governments. In the city of Chutcuendi in Republic of Uctusautia, a protectorate of Esalnira, empress Maionareta holds a conference in order to draft a coalition and alliance treaty against Cafonia. I Am You And You Are Me, the new fantasy TV series, premiered with a captivating and intricate episode that sets the stage for a geopolitical saga. The first episode showcases an intricate and dynamic world, full of political intrigue, power struggles, and social unrest.

The story centers around the rise of Cafonian Sea Khanate, an aggressive power that just conquered almost the entire Empire of Tzadriel. The state had been experiencing a deep political and economic crisis for a long time, which left it vulnerable to Cafonia's conquest. Empress Auvrittoht of Tzadriel manages to escape to the Federal Dominion of Esalnira, where she begins to organize the government-in-exile.

Meanwhile, imperial count Baisnef of Valdindet, with some support from independent grand duke Feszonmondt of Grand Duchy Skabak, reconquers the island of Varosia and is elected as emperor of Tzadriel by his supporters. These events create a tumultuous situation in the region, with the balance of power shaken by recent developments.

The episode also introduces us to some of the major players in this political chessboard, including empress Maiovareia of Esalnira, supreme chieftain Moistin of United Tribes of Bouxermon, and pacifist prophet and philosopher Leidomadt, whose teachings are opposed by different factions.

The visual effects and production design are top-notch, creating a believable and immersive world. The acting is also notable, with the cast delivering compelling and nuanced performances.

One of the episode's highlights is the coalition and alliance treaty signed by various factions, including Esalnira, Tzadriel government-in-exile, Viceroyalty of New Tzadriel, Bouxermon, Uctusautia, Skabak, League of Restrorigas, High Kingdom of Vendinares, Divine Principality of Amastavi, Kingdom of Fonzia, Duchy of Zwinde, Cerlichian Republic, Duchy of Jatha, and Duchy of Kaldinguk. This treaty not only shows the scale of the conflict but also highlights the complexity of alliances and loyalties in this world.

Overall, the premiere of I Am You And You Are Me is a fantastic start to an epic fantasy series. It creates a rich and intricate world, introduces several compelling characters, and sets the stage for a thrilling story full of political machinations, battles, and alliances. This is a must-watch for fans of the genre.
